perturbation.original_text: Failure by Allied to perform and comply with any of its obligations in sections 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12 and 13 of this Agreement shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement and Newegg shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately if Allied fails to cure the breach within fifteen (15) days following Newegg’s written notice of the breach.
perturbation.changed_text: Failure by Allied to perform and comply with any of its obligations in sections 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12 and 13 of this Agreement shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement and Newegg shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately if Allied fails to cure the breach within five (5) days following Newegg’s written notice of the breach.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a 15-day cure period for breaches. Reducing this to 5 days may conflict with California law, which often requires a reasonable cure period, especially for material breaches of contract. A court might deem 5 days insufficient depending on the nature of the breach and the effort required for cure.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California contract law regarding reasonable cure periods for material breaches.

perturbation.original_text: Before any Party (the “Complaining Party”) may bring any legal proceeding against the other (the “Non Complaining Party”), the Complaining Party shall first make a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve all disputes privately by notifying and providing to the Non Complaining Party of the Complaining Party’s complaints, reasons and supporting evidence for the complaints, and the reasonable steps Complaining Party would like the Non Complaining Party to take in order to address the complaints. If for any reason the Non-Complaining Party disagrees with either the complaint or the steps suggested to address the complaints, the Parties shall discuss and work on an amicable solution for at least thirty (30) days before the Complaining Party may bring any legal proceeding to resolve the complaints.
perturbation.changed_text: Before any Party (the “Complaining Party”) may bring any legal proceeding against the other (the “Non Complaining Party”), the Complaining Party shall first make a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve all disputes privately by notifying and providing to the Non Complaining Party of the Complaining Party’s complaints, reasons and supporting evidence for the complaints, and the reasonable steps Complaining Party would like the Non Complaining Party to take in order to address the complaints. If for any reason the Non-Complaining Party disagrees with either the complaint or the steps suggested to address the complaints, the Parties shall discuss and work on an amicable solution for at least ten (10) days before the Complaining Party may bring any legal proceeding to resolve the complaints.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates a 30-day negotiation period before legal proceedings can commence. Reducing this to 10 days might be deemed an unreasonably short timeframe under California law, potentially frustrating dispute resolution. Courts generally expect parties to engage in meaningful pre-litigation efforts, and 10 days could be seen as insufficient, especially for complex commercial disputes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California law regarding good faith negotiation and reasonable pre-litigation dispute resolution efforts.

perturbation.original_text: If posted, the notice shall be deemed to have been received five (5) working days after the date of posting or, in the case of a notice to an addressee not in the country of the sender, ten (10) working days after the date of posting. If sent by facsimile or electronic transmission, notice shall be deemed received upon confirmation of complete receipt being given by the intended receiving Party.
perturbation.changed_text: If posted, the notice shall be deemed to have been received fifteen (15) working days after the date of posting, regardless of the recipient's location. If sent by facsimile or electronic transmission, notice shall be deemed received three (3) days after the transmission date, regardless of confirmation.
perturbation.explanation: The changed text establishes a uniform 15-day receipt period for mailed notices, regardless of whether the recipient is located domestically or internationally, which contradicts typical expectations of international mail delivery times. In addition, stating that fax or electronic transmission is received 3 days after the transmission, regardless of confirmation, will be difficult to prove in court.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract laws, the parties did not receive proper notice.
